close_symbols: Internal filesystem record(s) / table(s) that store device/volume name buffers (definitions)
Size-limit constants for name/path buffers (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN or any FS name-size macros)
explanation:
Why each symbol is required:

- OS_FileSys_Initialize
  - This is the direct callee from OS_initfs. Any use of string.h functions (strcpy/strncpy/strcat/strlen/etc.) that could create out-of-bounds accesses will occur here or in functions it calls. You need the full implementation to see whether devname/volname/address are copied/truncated safely.

- OS_FileSysFormatVolume_Impl, OS_FileSysStartVolume_Impl, OS_FileSysStopVolume_Impl
  - These are direct callees of OS_FileSys_Initialize (per the static graph). They are likely to manipulate device and volume name strings or file-system internal buffers. Their source is required to check for unsafe string.h usages and destination buffer sizes.

- OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew, OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken
  - These routines manage object records/tokens and commonly copy or store object names into fixed-size record fields. To determine if copying of devname/volname by OS_FileSys_Initialize (or its callees) can overflow destination name buffers, the implementations of these allocation/finalization routines and how they handle string copies must be inspected.

- Internal filesystem record(s) / table(s) that store device/volume name buffers (definitions)
  - The concrete struct(s) (e.g. the file-system table entry type) that hold device/volume names are required so you can determine the actual destination buffer sizes and whether any copy operations respect those bounds.

- Size-limit constants for name/path buffers (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN or any FS name-size macros)
  - If copies/truncation use fixed-size buffers, you must know the compile-time constants that define those sizes to evaluate whether a string.h call can write beyond the buffer.

- OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE, OS_ERR_NO_FREE_IDS, OS_FS_ERR_DEVICE_NOT_FREE
  - These return-code macros/constants appear in OS_initfs and are used to map historic return values. While they do not directly affect string handling, including them ensures the analyzer understands control-flow/return-value mapping and can focus on the right execution paths (e.g., whether initialization proceeds into code paths that perform string copies).

(Notes)
- If any of the above implementations call other helpers that operate on strings, include those helpers as well. The analysis needs the call chain down to the point where any string.h function is invoked and the declaration/size of the destination buffers involved.
